name: Computing Everywhere
description: As mobile devices proliferate, Gartner predicted increased emphasis on serving users in diverse contexts and environments rather than focusing on devices alone.
accuracyNote: The prediction — 'serving users in diverse contexts rather than focusing on devices' — was so vague it says almost nothing specific. Any improvement in responsive design or UX counts as validation. Consulting-speak, not a falsifiable prediction.

name: The Internet of Things
description: IoT would be a transformative force, with organizations monetizing data from connected devices and creating new services and business models.
accuracyNote: Partially true — industrial IoT delivered value in manufacturing and logistics, but the transformative consumer IoT revolution was slower than expected.

name: 3D Printing
description: Continued predictions of rapid 3D printing adoption, with shipments expected to double again and use cases expanding across industries.
accuracyNote: Still overhyped — growth continued in industrial applications but the consumer revolution didn't materialize. Gartner kept this on the list too long.

name: Advanced, Pervasive and Invisible Analytics
description: Analytics would be embedded everywhere — in every app, every process, every employee's workflow. Big data would move from specialized to pervasive.
accuracyNote: Analytics became more widespread in SaaS products, but 'invisible analytics embedded in every process' overstates reality. Most workers still use spreadsheets; BI improved but still requires deliberate effort.

name: Context-Rich Systems
description: Systems would use contextual information (location, activity, preferences, social connections) to proactively anticipate user needs and deliver personalized experiences.
accuracyNote: Largely accurate — recommendation engines, personalization, and context-aware notifications became ubiquitous in apps like Spotify, Netflix, and Google Maps.

name: Smart Machines
description: Deep learning, neural networks, and natural language processing would advance rapidly, creating autonomous agents and smart advisors.
accuracyNote: Gartner predicted autonomous agents and smart advisors via deep learning and NLP. While deep learning did advance, the actual breakthroughs (transformers, LLMs) followed a completely different path than the neural net + reinforcement learning approach envisioned. The outcome loosely matches, but the mechanism and timeline were wrong.

name: Cloud/Client Computing
description: Cloud and mobile would converge, with synchronized apps and services spanning client devices and cloud backends becoming the dominant model.
accuracyNote: 'Synchronized apps spanning client devices and cloud backends' describes how the internet already worked in 2015, not a bold prediction. Directionally correct but not prescient.

name: Software-Defined Infrastructure
description: Programmable infrastructure would become the standard, with APIs replacing manual configuration across networking, storage, and compute.
accuracyNote: Terraform, Kubernetes, and cloud APIs became industry standard. But 'APIs replacing manual configuration' was already underway — more observing a trend than predicting one.

name: Web-Scale IT
description: More enterprises would adopt the operational models of hyperscale cloud providers, including self-service, automation, and agile development.
accuracyNote: DevOps and cloud-native practices became mainstream, but this was a vague prediction that anything cloud-related validates. Many enterprises still haven't fully adopted web-scale practices.

name: Risk-Based Security and Self-Protection
description: Security would shift from perimeter defense to application self-protection and risk-based approaches, with security embedded into applications themselves.
accuracyNote: Accurate — zero trust architecture, DevSecOps, and runtime application self-protection (RASP) emerged as predicted, though adoption was slower than hoped.
